meta_data.title: The Scouring of Jerusalemshire
meta_data.subtitle: Nehemiah 13:23-27  Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: You're listening to the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. It's fast, fun, free daily deep-dye Bible and right now we're working on the book of Nehemiah. If you're new, welcome. You can jump in right here or you can always go back and start at the beginning of any season. The whole podcast is available in an easy-to-use format at thetmbh.com. Hey my friends, I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast and if you want to know the difference between somebody who watched and really enjoyed, what was I guys saying? Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy and someone who read repeatedly and really enjoyed J.R.R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings trilogy of books, there are a couple things that'll give it away. Your book readers are going to want to talk about a character named Tom Bombadil. We're not going to talk about Tom Bombadil but it's just a thing. It's one of the cues. Your book readers are also going to want to talk about a whole scene that got left out of the movies. The scene is called, some of you are already yelling it, it happens there at the end, it's called the scouring of the Shire. And what happens is the adventurers, they go on this grand quest and they change and they defeat a great evil and they come back and they discover that in their absence their hometown has gone to rot. That goons and thugs have taken over and the beloved Shire which is a metaphor for the ideal world in which Tolkien lived one untouched by the horrors of World War I. It got overrun and turned bleak and dark and bad and so they went out to defeat this great darkness but then the one thing that had been good got out of control and it was ugly and so the heroes come back and now with all of their newfound strength and ability and battle-hardened testedness they come back and easily dispatch with the jerks who were ruining the idyllic Shire. Likewise in Nehemiah 13 we have the scouring of Jerusalem. Nehemiah has gone to deal with grand affairs of state and he left Jerusalem in a good state to go and deal with big things concerning the Persian Empire. The bigger more pressing matters on the mind of his buddy and king Artaxerxes the first and he makes his way back to Jerusalem in Nehemiah 13 and finds out that goons and thugs have taken things over and they've made a mess of everything and so he scours it. He purifies the mess and it is a bit violent. Yesterday we speculated a little bit about what that violence looked like and how exactly he carried it out and it is an interesting thing to think about but today I want to talk about once the violence is over and we get to the very last part of Nehemiah 13 where he pours out his heart to the people he's yelling at. He is trying to explain to them why he is scouring, why he is disciplining Jerusalem and the people who are getting it wrong in the way he is and it comes down to a contrast between the people who get it right and the people who get it wrong that has been present for all of Nehemiah and the prequel to Nehemiah which is called Ezra. The contrast is this the people who get it right in Ezra and Nehemiah see the whole grand story of the Bible. They understand that all the descendants of Abraham, the Hebrews, the Israelites, the Jews, they're all part of a big grand story. They're all part of a deal made with God a thousand plus years earlier where God said I'm going to be your God you're going to be my people and everybody's going to know that that's true and if you obey these things I'm telling you everybody's going to know I'm your God because I'm going to bless you so much and if you disobey these things that I'm telling you everybody's still going to know that I'm the one true God because I'm going to punish you so much and that is what sets up the whole narrative flow of the entire Old Testament. Ezra got that, Nehemiah got that I think is a rubable a character from early on in the book of Ezra who helped rebuild the temple in the 530s BC I think he got that but nobody seems to get it as clearly as Nehemiah. Nobody seems to feel it as deeply as Nehemiah so the people are the good guys in these books they get the story the people who are the dolts in these books they don't get the story they think they're a part of nothing they think it's just about them they're just doing something or whatever feels good in the moment and Nehemiah has been both metaphorically and now literally grabbing them by the shoulders and shaking and being like see the story it's a story if you look at all of it you'll figure out what it takes to be the good guy and you'll figure out what it looks like to be the bad guy yes I am still shaking with both of my hands right here in real life alone in my basement this is just how the things are right now he doesn't just want them to do the right behavior when he's there to supervise them and pull their hair out if they disobey he wants them to get the story he wants them to internalize it for themselves he wants them to become vested he wants them to feel the importance of their role and their standing in this whole thing he wants them to feel custody and ownership of this story not just of the well-being of their own people but of the whole of God's redemptive plan Nehemiah gets it these people don't get it so now we get to the part where Nehemiah makes his heartfelt plea with clumps of hair and maybe a bit of bloody scalp laying around on the ground and people rubbing their heads in disappointment and maybe some Persian guards who had had spears leveled at these people with Nehemiah now walking over and putting two fingers on the tip of that brandish spear making eye contact with his men to say settle down we're not going to run anybody through now he talks to these people now he makes one last plea before the book is out for them to get what they need to get to get this right here's how it goes Nehemiah 1325 you're not to give your daughters and marriage to their sons nor are you to take their daughters and marriage for your sons or for yourselves wasn't it because a marriage is like these the Solomon king of Israel sinned among the many nations there was no king like him he was loved by his god and god made him king over all Israel but even he was led into sin by foreign women must we hear now that you two are doing this terrible wickedness and are being unfaithful to our god by marrying foreign women quickly let's just address the elephant in the room this is your first time here you're probably like dang so he's a great big misogynist we've covered it a whole bunch in previous conversations different time different situation and also completely different social order you're talking I mean the reason that we're using this language about marrying foreign women is going to have a ton to do with the system of dowries and the transitions of wealth and the blending of households the Israelite people were the ones who were settled they had walled cities they had money they had to pay out that money and enter into business arrangements through arranged marriages with foreign wives so if you think of it in terms of Disney modern love it's going to sound kind of weird and kind of jerky but very different time very different set of socio economic standards for how life was done again we've covered a whole lot of that before if you're interested in that go back and catch the rest of the conversation on neomy it'll make more sense so acknowledging that this language was written in a different time in a different place than the moment in time in which we live you can still get to the heart of what he's saying right this is our Achilles heel this is how we keep screwing up I referenced yesterday the Obi-Wan and Anakin conversation you were the chosen one you had a role to play here Obi-Wan is appealing to the story with Anakin Nehemiah is appealing to the story with these guys you're chosen by God we're unique people we play a unique and redemptive role for all of humanity and you guys are screwing around with it for stupid reasons don't do that and I love the way he makes the point it's almost as though he's saying like do you think you're above it do you think this doesn't apply to you guys if it applied to Solomon the dude who was the wisest of anybody ever and who represents the height of our wealth and the height of our ancestral territory and imperial dominance if it could take him down guys it can take you down if it could take his robust kingdom down it can take our fledgling baby not even kingdom down that is just a little tiny province and a little tiny blip on the map in the larger Persian empire where we're still subservient to a foreign king we're fragile here we don't have anywhere near the solid footing of Solomon and it broke him the kingdom split into one generation after Solomon because of this you think we're better than that you think we can afford that have we learned nothing there's obviously a deep disappointment but there is a deep sincerity to his pleading here he clearly still believes that this narrative can be understood by other people he still believes that his fellow countrymen the heads of these households can stop thinking in the moment and can start thinking of the grand story and he believes that if they will just do that their behavior will fall into line their lives will fall into line they will obey and honor the covenants they've agreed to they'll obey the commands of god and god's blessing will be upon these people so i think it's kind of interesting that he didn't really come in and give him the speech about you want to do this the easy way or the hard way he came in and was basically i'm not even going to ask you we're going to do this the easy way and the hard way so we're going to start with beatings and pulling your hair out and now we're going to do the part where it's the grandfatherly sincere heartfelt talk and challenge to please please please please understand what is going on here understand your role understand your custody of the situation and get this right when i'm not around get it right because you're vested get it right because you own it and you get it there's a tiny bit more of nehemiah's scouring of Jerusalem here at the end of the chapter just a couple verses left but that's pretty much it the pattern is pretty straightforward he sees the violation of the three points of the covenant vows that everybody had made all these people have agreed to in nehemiah 10 he goes in with his own hands addresses the problem not with paperwork he fixes it physically and then he repairs the part of the covenant that was broken he does that in relationship to Tobias presence in the temple he does that in relationship to the violations of the Sabbath and how business was being conducted improperly and then he does that in relation to these new marriages that are in violation of the covenant standards for marriage what's unique is that in this third one we get that little speech that we looked at today that is a plea for an understanding of what the story is and what their place is in it all told i don't know what else nehemiah can do he can't be alive forever he can't be there forever the very thing that gives him the political credibility to show up and do this with the authority of the king is the very thing that demands he not be in Jerusalem all the time he has to go back and actually serve the king and actually do his actual job so this last play on the part of nehemiah is really all he has left to offer the situation and i think we're going to see as we get into the epilogue of this season and of this book that it kind of worked sort of he does end up winning but only sort of it's maybe a bit of a pyrrhic victory the results are certainly mixed and the results certainly evolve but nehemiah and desra do succeed in ushering in a whole new era of Judaism a whole new chapter of this story but even though they achieve that they don't ultimately solve the heart of the problem and obviously we'll talk about that a lot more as we get into epilogue zone here after we cover the last few verses next time around i'm matt this is the 10 minute bible hour podcast let's do this again soon

welcome. You can jump in right here or you can always go back and start at the
beginning of any season. The whole podcast is available in an easy-to-use
format at thetmbh.com. Hey my friends, I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour
Podcast and if you want to know the difference between somebody who watched
and really enjoyed, what was I guys saying? Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings
trilogy and someone who read repeatedly and really enjoyed J.R.R. Tolkien's Lord
of the Rings trilogy of books, there are a couple things that'll give it away. Your
book readers are going to want to talk about a character named Tom Bombadil.
We're not going to talk about Tom Bombadil but it's just a thing. It's one of
the cues. Your book readers are also going to want to talk about a whole
scene that got left out of the movies. The scene is called, some of you are already
yelling it, it happens there at the end, it's called the scouring of the Shire.
And what happens is the adventurers, they go on this grand quest and they change and
they defeat a great evil and they come back and they discover that in their
absence their hometown has gone to rot. That goons and thugs have taken over and
the beloved Shire which is a metaphor for the ideal world in which Tolkien lived one untouched
by the horrors of World War I. It got overrun and turned bleak and dark and bad and so they went
out to defeat this great darkness but then the one thing that had been good got out of control
and it was ugly and so the heroes come back and now with all of their newfound strength and
ability and battle-hardened testedness they come back and easily dispatch with the jerks who were
ruining the idyllic Shire. Likewise in Nehemiah 13 we have the scouring of Jerusalem. Nehemiah
has gone to deal with grand affairs of state and he left Jerusalem in a good state to go and deal
with big things concerning the Persian Empire. The bigger more pressing matters on the mind of his
buddy and king Artaxerxes the first and he makes his way back to Jerusalem in Nehemiah 13
and finds out that goons and thugs have taken things over and they've made a mess of everything
and so he scours it. He purifies the mess and it is a bit violent. Yesterday we speculated a little
bit about what that violence looked like and how exactly he carried it out and it is an interesting
thing to think about but today I want to talk about once the violence is over and we get to the
very last part of Nehemiah 13 where he pours out his heart to the people he's yelling at.
He is trying to explain to them why he is scouring, why he is disciplining Jerusalem and the people
who are getting it wrong in the way he is and it comes down to a contrast between the people who
get it right and the people who get it wrong that has been present for all of Nehemiah and the
prequel to Nehemiah which is called Ezra. The contrast is this the people who get it right
in Ezra and Nehemiah see the whole grand story of the Bible. They understand that all the descendants
of Abraham, the Hebrews, the Israelites, the Jews, they're all part of a big grand story.
They're all part of a deal made with God a thousand plus years earlier where God said I'm
going to be your God you're going to be my people and everybody's going to know that that's true
and if you obey these things I'm telling you everybody's going to know I'm your God because
I'm going to bless you so much and if you disobey these things that I'm telling you everybody's
still going to know that I'm the one true God because I'm going to punish you so much and that
is what sets up the whole narrative flow of the entire Old Testament. Ezra got that, Nehemiah got
that I think is a rubable a character from early on in the book of Ezra who helped rebuild the
temple in the 530s BC I think he got that but nobody seems to get it as clearly as Nehemiah.
Nobody seems to feel it as deeply as Nehemiah so the people are the good guys in these books
they get the story the people who are the dolts in these books they don't get the story
they think they're a part of nothing they think it's just about them they're just doing something
or whatever feels good in the moment and Nehemiah has been both metaphorically and now literally
grabbing them by the shoulders and shaking and being like see the story it's a story if you look at
all of it you'll figure out what it takes to be the good guy and you'll figure out what it looks
like to be the bad guy yes I am still shaking with both of my hands right here in real life alone
in my basement this is just how the things are right now he doesn't just want them to do the right
behavior when he's there to supervise them and pull their hair out if they disobey he wants them
to get the story he wants them to internalize it for themselves he wants them to become vested
he wants them to feel the importance of their role and their standing in this whole thing he
wants them to feel custody and ownership of this story not just of the well-being of their own
people but of the whole of God's redemptive plan Nehemiah gets it these people don't get it
so now we get to the part where Nehemiah makes his heartfelt plea with clumps of hair and maybe a
bit of bloody scalp laying around on the ground and people rubbing their heads in disappointment
and maybe some Persian guards who had had spears leveled at these people with Nehemiah now walking
over and putting two fingers on the tip of that brandish spear making eye contact with his men to
say settle down we're not going to run anybody through now he talks to these people now he makes
one last plea before the book is out for them to get what they need to get to get this right
here's how it goes Nehemiah 1325 you're not to give your daughters and marriage to their sons
nor are you to take their daughters and marriage for your sons or for yourselves wasn't it because
a marriage is like these the Solomon king of Israel sinned among the many nations there was no king
like him he was loved by his god and god made him king over all Israel but even he was led into sin
by foreign women must we hear now that you two are doing this terrible wickedness and are being
unfaithful to our god by marrying foreign women quickly let's just address the elephant in the
room this is your first time here you're probably like dang so he's a great big misogynist we've
covered it a whole bunch in previous conversations different time different situation and also
completely different social order you're talking I mean the reason that we're using this language
about marrying foreign women is going to have a ton to do with the system of dowries and the
transitions of wealth and the blending of households the Israelite people were the ones who were settled
they had walled cities they had money they had to pay out that money and enter into business
arrangements through arranged marriages with foreign wives so if you think of it in terms of
Disney modern love it's going to sound kind of weird and kind of jerky but very different time
very different set of socio economic standards for how life was done again we've covered a whole
lot of that before if you're interested in that go back and catch the rest of the conversation
on neomy it'll make more sense so acknowledging that this language was written in a different
time in a different place than the moment in time in which we live you can still get to the heart
of what he's saying right this is our Achilles heel this is how we keep screwing up I referenced
yesterday the Obi-Wan and Anakin conversation you were the chosen one you had a role to play here
Obi-Wan is appealing to the story with Anakin Nehemiah is appealing to the story with these guys
you're chosen by God we're unique people we play a unique and redemptive role for all of humanity
and you guys are screwing around with it for stupid reasons don't do that and I love the way
he makes the point it's almost as though he's saying like do you think you're above it do you
think this doesn't apply to you guys if it applied to Solomon the dude who was the wisest of anybody
ever and who represents the height of our wealth and the height of our ancestral territory and
imperial dominance if it could take him down guys it can take you down if it could take his robust
kingdom down it can take our fledgling baby not even kingdom down that is just a little tiny
province and a little tiny blip on the map in the larger Persian empire where we're still
subservient to a foreign king we're fragile here we don't have anywhere near the solid footing of
Solomon and it broke him the kingdom split into one generation after Solomon because of this
you think we're better than that you think we can afford that have we learned nothing there's
obviously a deep disappointment but there is a deep sincerity to his pleading here he clearly
still believes that this narrative can be understood by other people he still believes that his
fellow countrymen the heads of these households can stop thinking in the moment and can start
thinking of the grand story and he believes that if they will just do that their behavior will
fall into line their lives will fall into line they will obey and honor the covenants they've agreed
to they'll obey the commands of god and god's blessing will be upon these people so i think
it's kind of interesting that he didn't really come in and give him the speech about you want to do
this the easy way or the hard way he came in and was basically i'm not even going to ask you we're
going to do this the easy way and the hard way so we're going to start with beatings and pulling
your hair out and now we're going to do the part where it's the grandfatherly sincere heartfelt talk
and challenge to please please please please understand what is going on here understand your
role understand your custody of the situation and get this right when i'm not around get it right
because you're vested get it right because you own it and you get it there's a tiny bit more of
nehemiah's scouring of Jerusalem here at the end of the chapter just a couple verses left but that's
pretty much it the pattern is pretty straightforward he sees the violation of the three points of the
covenant vows that everybody had made all these people have agreed to in nehemiah 10 he goes in
with his own hands addresses the problem not with paperwork he fixes it physically and then
he repairs the part of the covenant that was broken he does that in relationship to Tobias
presence in the temple he does that in relationship to the violations of the Sabbath and how business
was being conducted improperly and then he does that in relation to these new marriages that are
in violation of the covenant standards for marriage what's unique is that in this third one we get
that little speech that we looked at today that is a plea for an understanding of what the story
is and what their place is in it all told i don't know what else nehemiah can do he can't be alive
forever he can't be there forever the very thing that gives him the political credibility to show
up and do this with the authority of the king is the very thing that demands he not be in Jerusalem
all the time he has to go back and actually serve the king and actually do his actual job so this
last play on the part of nehemiah is really all he has left to offer the situation
and i think we're going to see as we get into the epilogue of this season and of this book that
it kind of worked sort of he does end up winning but only sort of it's maybe a bit of a pyrrhic
victory the results are certainly mixed and the results certainly evolve but
nehemiah and desra do succeed in ushering in a whole new era of Judaism a whole new chapter of
this story but even though they achieve that they don't ultimately solve the heart of the problem
and obviously we'll talk about that a lot more as we get into epilogue zone here after we cover
the last few verses next time around i'm matt this is the 10 minute bible hour podcast let's do this
again soon
